wikipedia_page.main: William Thomas Fry (1789–1843) was a British engraver. He occasionally exhibited his engravings at the Suffolk Street exhibition.

response: *  An engraving by William Thomas Fry of a painting by Burney in Forget Me Not, 1824, with an accompanying poem by Letitia Elizabeth Landon.
There were engravings included by William Thomas Fry, James Thomson, and Richard Woodman.
A portrait of Scott, drawn by John Jackson R.A. in 1823, was engraved by William Thomas Fry and published in 1826. A crayon portrait by his son went to the print-room of the British Museum.

Thomas Wright (1792–1849) was an engraver and portrait-painter. He served as an apprentice to Henry Meyer, and worked for four years as assistant to William Thomas Fry, for whom he engraved the popular plate of Princess Charlotte and Prince Leopold in a box at Covent Garden Theatre. About 1817 he began to practise independently as a stipple-engraver, and also found employment in taking portraits in pencil and miniature.
In the 1820s, Holl was one of the early adopters of the steel plate engraving technique pioneered by Charles Warren; others in the field were William Thomas Fry and Charles Marr.
